{{Infobox scientist | honorific_prefix = | name = Thomas Oakland | honorific_suffix = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = | image_size = | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Thomas David Oakland | birth_date = {{birth date|1939|11|23}} | birth_place = [[Kenosha]], [[Wisconsin]] | death_date = {{death date and age |2015|03|04|1939|11|23}} | death_place = [[Gainesville, Florida|Gainesville]], [[Florida]] | death_cause = [[Murder]] | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | home_town = | other_names = | pronounce = | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = [[United States|American]] | fields = [[Educational psychology]]
[[School psychology]] | workplaces = [[University of Texas at Austin]]
[[University of Florida]] | patrons = | education = [[Indiana University]] | alma_mater = | thesis_title = Social class and performance on phonemic and nonphonemic auditory discrimination tests | thesis_url = http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/23226888 | thesis_year = 1967 | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = | influences = | influenced = | awards = [[Fulbright Scholarship]] (1988){{Cite news |url=https://www.alligator.org/news/campus/former-uf-professor-s-life-career-celebrated-by-family/article_9585417c-d69c-11e4-bff5-63a26e98e28b.html |title=Former UF professor’s life, career celebrated by family |last=Cochrane |first=Emily |date=2015-03-30 |work=[[The Independent Florida Alligator]] |access-date=2018-11-05 |language=en}}
[[APA Award for Distinguished Contributions to the International Advancement of Psychology]] (2003){{Cite journal |date=November 2003 |title=Thomas D. Oakland: Award for Distinguished Contributions to the International Advancement of Psychology |journal=[[The American Psychologist]] |volume=58 |issue=11 |pages=983–985 |doi=10.1037/0003-066X.58.11.983 |issn=0003-066X |pmid=14609396}} | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | spouse = Judy Higgins | partner = | children = David Thomas Oakland
Christopher Oakland | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Thomas David Oakland''' (November 23, 1939 – March 4, 2015) was an American school and educational psychologist who taught at the [[University of Florida]] from 1995 until retiring in 2010. He previously taught at the [[University of Texas at Austin]] for 27 years.{{Cite web |url=https://education.ufl.edu/news/2015/03/09/coe-responds-to-tragic-death-of-professor-emeritus-thomas-oakland/ |title=COE responds to tragic death of Professor Emeritus Thomas Oakland |date=2015-03-09 |website=COE News |publisher=[[University of Florida College of Education]] |access-date=2018-11-05}} He was a fellow of the [[American Psychological Society]] and of four divisions of the [[American Psychological Association]].{{Cite journal |last=Jimerson |first=Shane R. |authorlink=Shane R. Jimerson|date=September 2015 |title=Thomas D. Oakland (1939-2015) |journal=The American Psychologist |volume=70 |issue=6 |pages=567 |doi=10.1037/a0039485 |issn=1935-990X |pmid=26348339}} ==Death== Oakland was murdered at his home on March 4, 2015, at the age of 75. Local police alleged at the time that Stephen Underwood Jr., an ex-convict whom Oakland had previously given over $37,000 in cash, fatally struck Oakland in the head and body. Police also claimed that Underwood then stole money from Oakland's home before setting it on fire. Underwood was soon arrested and charged with [[murder]], [[arson]], [[burglary]], and [[grand theft]].{{Cite news |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/retired-univ-of-florida-professor-thomas-oakland-was-bludgeoned-before-house-fire-suspect/ |title=Retired Univ. of Florida professor gave suspect $37K before alleged murder |date=2015-03-06 |website=[[CBS News]] |language=en |access-date=2018-11-05}} In February 2018, Underwood was found guilty of Oakland's murder and sentenced to 50 years in prison.{{Cite news |url=https://www.wcjb.com/content/news/Man-sentenced-in-UF-professors-murder-472862363.html |title=Man sentenced in UF professor's murder |last=Jones |first=David |date=2018-02-05 |website=[[WCJB]] |language=en |access-date=2018-11-05}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== *{{Cite magazine |last=Fagan |first=Tom |date=2015-09-01 |title=Remembering Tom Oakland |url=https://www.questia.com/magazine/1P3-3859273991/remembering-tom-oakland |magazine=Communiqué |publisher=[[National Association of School Psychologists]] |access-date=2018-11-05}} {{Authority control|VIAF=2567512|LCCN=n83055941}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Oakland, Thomas David}} [[Category:1939 births]] [[Category:2015 deaths]] [[Category:Murdered American scientists]] [[Category:University of Florida faculty]] [[Category:Educational psychologists]] [[Category:American psychologists]] [[Category:University of Texas at Austin faculty]] [[Category:Indiana University alumni]] [[Category:People from Kenosha, Wisconsin]] [[Category:Fellows of the Association for Psychological Science]] {{US-psychologist-stub}}

{{for|the other American novelist|Tom McHale (novelist born 1902)}} {{Infobox writer |name = Tom McHale |image = |caption = Tom McHale – 1971 |birth_date = 1941 |birth_place = [[Avoca, Pennsylvania]] |death_date = March 30, 1982 |death_place = [[Pembroke Pines, Florida]] |occupation = Novelist |genre = [[Satire]], [[Black comedy]] |movement = |notableworks = ''Principato'',
''Farragan's Retreat'' |influences = |footnotes = |signature = }} '''Tom McHale''' (1941 – March 30, 1982) was an American novelist. His works include ''Principato'', ''Farragan's Retreat'' (nominated for the [[National Book Award]]), ''Alinsky's Diamond'', ''School Spirit'', ''The Lady from Boston'', and ''Dear Friends''. He was born in [[Avoca, Pennsylvania]] and received a Master of Fine Arts degree from the [[University of Iowa]]. He committed suicide in [[Florida]] in 1982. ==Early life== Thomas "Tom" McHale was born in 1941 in [[Avoca, Pennsylvania]] located nine miles (15 km) southwest of [[Scranton, Pennsylvania|Scranton]]. He was the eldest of six children from an [[Irish-Catholic]] family.{{cite web|url=http://www.litencyc.com/php/speople.php?rec=true&UID=5402 |title=Tom McHale |accessdate=2010-07-01|work=|first=Martin |last=Kich |publisher=The Literary Encyclopedia - June 20, 2003}} His family’s Irish-American ethnicity and Roman Catholicism would become prominent elements in his novels. He worked as a caseworker for the Department of Public Assistance in Philadelphia for a brief period. He attended [[Jesuit]] Catholic schools including ''Scranton Preparatory'' (1955–1959) and was a graduate of [[Temple University]] in the early 1960s. He went on to earn a Master of Fine Arts from the [[University of Iowa]] Writers Workshop. He had planned to be a doctor and attended medical school but changed his mind and dropped out.{{cite news |title=From Book to Brick |first=Phil |last=Thomas|newspaper=The Citizen Auburn |location=[[Auburn, New York]] |date=May 9, 1976}} ==Career== After the success of his first novel, ''Principato'' in 1972, McHale secured the position of ''writer-in-residence'' at [[Monmouth University]] in [[West Long Branch, New Jersey]], a position he held until the end of his life. Shortly before his death he was rewarded with a teaching position at the [[University of Pennsylvania]] that was to commence in fall semester, September, 1983.{{cite news |title=Portrait of a Writer as a Young Suicide |first=Cathy Lynn |last=Grossman |newspaper=[[Miami Herald]] |location=[[Miami, Florida]] |date=July 4, 1983}} McHale took an interest in writing early on, however, after attending a wedding in Israel in the late 1960s he decided to "give the writing monster inside me a chance and stayed there a year to see what I could do, to see if anything came up. I wrote a first novel. It was so bad that I tore it up into little pieces, took it out to the [[Negev Desert]] and threw it all over." Shortly after, he wrote a second novel and traveled to Paris, France where he shared it with the widow of novelist [[Richard Wright (author)|Richard Wright]]. She liked what she saw and the book was later published as ''Principato'', McHale's first important work. By the 1970s he was one of the most promising American novelists of his generation. During a period of 12 years between 1970 and 1982, he produced six novels that received wide acclaim and positive reviews. In 1976, McHale noted that he "writes in longhand, then has his work transcribed by a typist he describes as 'marvelous', she actually knows the English language and corrects my spelling and punctuation." He would spend an average of 18 months working on each novel but admitted that ''School Spirit'' only took him about seven months. During that period he was living in [[Boston, Massachusetts]] and expressed that he would like to work on a movie script because next because "I'm terribly interested in film. It's such a vast medium, so many people can see a movie. A novel, however, is limited in its appeal." McHale described his work; {{Quotation|Parts of all of my novels are funny. But there's a tragi-comic sense to all of them. You can't deny the comedy, but neither can you deny the tragedy. It's there.}} By 1972, Paramount pictures was very enthused about McHale's first novel, ''Farragan's Retreat''. They even hired [[screenwriter]] [[Ring Lardner Jr.]] to turn the novel into a screenplay. This was during the time of [[Richard Nixon]]'s election and Paramount eventually decided that the [[War in Vietnam]] was going to end soon. Because the book was about a young man who had gone to Canada to avoid the draft, the studio decided against using the story because they worried that by the time the film finally came out, the war would be over and the American public would have lost interest. As it turns out, Nixon prolonged the war, but by then Paramount had unfortunately moved on. Lardner mentioned several years later, in 1982, that he regretted that Paramount dropped the project because it was the screenplay he "liked the very best that never got made."{{cite news |title=Ring Lardner, Jr. |first=Lisa Faye |last=Kaplan |newspaper=Herald Statesman |location=[[Yonkers, New York]]|year=1982}} ===Reception=== Reviewers compared McHale's novels to those of [[Joseph Heller]], [[Kurt Vonnegut Jr.]], [[John Updike]] and [[Philip Roth]] because of his black comic humor. They also saw considerable talent in his quickly growing body of work. A [[New York Times]] review in March, 1971 noted that "There are many young writers with healthy reserves of rags and chaos, some indeed with little else. What distinguishes McHale is not only the fertility of his invention but the humanity—remarkable in a writer of 28—that penetrates even his crudest characters.".{{cite news |title=Books: Ring Around the Rosary |first=|last=|newspaper=[[New York Times]] |location=[[New York, New York]] |date=March 1, 1971}} An article in ''Life Magazine'' in 1971 went on to say that "McHale writes as if born to the craft. He imagines and schemes like a beery poet. He sees, pokes, probes. He tells fabulous jokes---McHale's capacity to trigger emotions ranges from laughter to compassion to cold horror. Realism, pathos, mystery, Tom McHale is not another new writer. He is himself."{{cite journal |title=A fusion of blasphemy and formality |first=Webster |last=Schott |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qFMEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA8&lpg=PA8&dq=%22tom+mchale%22+novelist&source=bl&ots=8VD4zgB67r&sig=MdUnQgF94N-Ed-t2wGQ8MDzQE-k&hl=en&ei=pHYtTI7bLYuCnQeU98TUAw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CCYQ6AEwBTgK#v=onepage&q&f=false |magazine=[[Life (magazine)|''Life'']] magazine |location=[[New York, New York]] |publisher=Time Inc. |date=February 5, 1971|accessdate=May 30, 2010}} By 1976, a review from [[Associated Press]] gave much credit to the novel ''School Spirit'' for grappling with "questions that men have long pondered, questions such as the sanctity of life, guilt, punishment, redemption, but instead of creating what should have been a heavy philosophic text, he successfully produced a comic novel that makes the reader think, even as he laughs."{{cite news |title=Book Reviews by AP |first=|last=|newspaper=The Citizen; [[Associated Press]] |location=[[Auburn, New York]] |date=April 11, 1976}} Despite many good reviews, not all were favorable. In 1971 a scathing review of ''Farragan's Retreat'' noted that "this is an absurd book that started well. Now that this talented author has this novel out of his system, we can only hope that he'll live up to his potential."{{cite news |title=Book Reviews |first=|last=|newspaper=The Citizen-Advertiser |location=[[Auburn, New York]] |work= |date=February 27, 1971}} ==Personal life== McHale was married to Suzanne McHale and had homes in [[Kittery, Maine]] and [[Killington, Vermont]]. McHale enjoyed working with masonry in his spare time. He started in his mid-twenties by building fieldstone walls and later built fireplaces. In 1976, he proudly talked about the home in Maine, 60 miles from Boston, that he was looking forward to the construction of that summer; "It'll give me a chance to do some physical work. Outside, I'll do the masonry work on the base of the house and inside, I'll do the fireplace." McHale committed suicide at age 40 at his sister’s home in [[Pembroke Pines, Florida]].{{cite web|url=http://www.edrants.com/tom-mchale-novelist/ |title=Tom McHale, novelist |accessdate=2010-07-01|work=|first=Richard |last=Grayson |publisher=Edward Champion's Reluctant Habits - May 23, 2007}} ===Bibliography=== * ''Principato'' (1970) – The novel was "almost universally hailed as a remarkable debut effort." This is religious fiction and is a story about ''Angelo Principato'', an [[Italian-American]] Catholic social worker from [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] who marries an [[Irish-Catholic]] girl named ''Cynthia Corrigan'' who is the daughter of a wealthy mortician.{{cite web|url=http://www.matthewstamand.com/supplemental/tom_mchale/principato.htm |title=Tom McHale - Principato |accessdate=2010-07-01|work=|first=Matthew |last=St. Amand |publisher=Matthew St. Amand - 2010}} * ''Farragan's Retreat'' (1972) – The book received even more enthusiastic reviews than ''Principato'' and was named a finalist for the [[National Book Award]] later that year. Like his first novel, it was a story about Irish and Italian Catholics in Philadelphia. * ''Alinsky's Diamond'' (1974) – Adeptly combined satire and comedy, by then a style very familiar to McHale. It is the story of ''Frances X. Murphy'', an [[Irish-American]] hustler who marries into a "fine" [[French people|French]] family. * ''School Spirit'' (1976) – Explored the consequences of exposing a "long-buried secret" and was McHale's first suspense novel." * ''The Lady from Boston'' (1978) – Dealt with the manipulation and betrayal of a young man by a beautiful woman and was far more cynical and darker than previous works. * ''Dear Friends'' (1982) – His last written work was a deeply dark novel about a lawyer whose life unravels in a matter of days after witnessing two suicides and later discovering his firstborn child was fathered by another man. ===Unfinished works=== * ''Elspath's War Canoe'' (1977) – A story about a young man who comes to Boston from Kansas City. He's determined to knock the world for a loop but he gets knocked instead. ===Awards=== In 1974, McHale was awarded the [[Guggenheim Fellowship]] for Fiction for ''Alinsky's Diamond''. He also received the ''Thomas More Association'' medal, an award given annually for the most distinguished contribution to Catholic Literature for his novel ''School Spirit'' in 1976.{{cite news |url=http://www.timesleader.com/pittstondispatch/peeking/Sheporaitis_initiated_recycling_in_1947_03-28-2010.html |title=Peeking into the past; 1977, 33 years ago |newspaper=Pittston Dispatch |location=[[Pittston, Pennsylvania]] |date=March 1, 1971 |accessdate=July 2, 2010}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.litencyc.com/php/speople.php?rec=true&UID=5402 Tom McHale at the Literary Encyclopedia] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:McHale, Tom}} [[Category:1941 births]] [[Category:1982 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century American novelists]] [[Category:American male novelists]] [[Category:Temple University alumni]] [[Category:University of Iowa alumni]] [[Category:Iowa Writers' Workshop alumni]] [[Category:Writers from Scranton, Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Suicides by carbon monoxide poisoning]] [[Category:Writers who committed suicide]] [[Category:Guggenheim Fellows]] [[Category:Male suicides]] [[Category:20th-century American male writers]] [[Category:Novelists from Pennsylvania]]

{{good article}} {{Infobox university |name = University of the Philippines Los Baños College of Forestry and Natural Resources |image = CFNR.svg |image_size = 200px |established = April 19, 1910 |type = [[Constituent college]] |dean = Juan M. Pulhin |city = {{flagicon|Philippines}} [[Los Baños, Laguna|Los Baños]] |province = [[Laguna province|Laguna]] |country = [[Philippines]] |faculty = 56<ref name="A Statement on the Large Class Size Project"/> |students = 487<ref name="A Statement on the Large Class Size Project"/> |undergrad = 393<ref name="A Statement on the Large Class Size Project"/> |postgrad = 20<ref name='GS 2010 statement'>{{Cite book | url = http://gs.uplb.edu.ph/index.php/downloads/doc_download/13-2010-graduate-school-annual-report | title = Graduate School Annual Report 2010 | publisher = University of the Philippines Los Baños Graduate School | year = 2010 | accessdate = 2011-06-12 | page = 9}}</ref> |coor={{Coord|14|9|17|N|121|14|6.25|E|region:PH_type:edu|display=inline,title}} |affiliations = Asia Pacific of Forestry Research Institutions, Philippine Agroforestry Education and Research Network |website = [http://cfnr.uplb.edu.ph/ cfnr.uplb.edu.ph] }}
The '''University of the Philippines Los Baños College of Forestry and Natural Resources''' (also referred to as '''CFNR''') is one of the 11 degree-granting units of the [[University of the Philippines Los Baños|University of the Philippines Los Baños (UPLB)]].<ref name='UPLB Acads'>{{cite web | url = http://www.uplb.edu.ph/index.php/schools-and-colleges | title = Schools and Colleges | publisher = University of the Philippines Los Baños | accessdate = 2011-04-24 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101201095332/http://uplb.edu.ph/index.php/schools-and-colleges | archivedate = 2010-12-01 | df = }}</ref> It started as the '''Forest School''' under the [[UP College of Agriculture]] in 1910, making it the oldest [[forestry school]] in the [[Philippines]].<ref name='Forest Congress'>{{cite thesis| url = http://www.fao.org/DOCREP/ARTICLE/WFC/XII/0513-C4.HTM | title = Assessment of Forestry Education in Southeast Asia | author = Juan M. Pulhin| publisher = XIII World Forestry Congress | date = 2003 | location = Quebec City | accessdate = 2011-04-30|display-authors=etal}}</ref> It is one of the five founding units of UPLB upon its establishment in 1972.<ref name = 'PD 58'>{{cite web| url = http://www.lawphil.net/statutes/presdecs/pd1972/pd_58_1972.html | title = Presidential Decree No. 58 | publisher = Arellano Law Foundation | author = Ferdinand E. Marcos | date = 1972-11-20 | accessdate = 2011-05-03}}</ref>
The college has been identified as a "Center of Excellence" in [[forestry]] by the [[Commission on Higher Education (Philippines)|Philippine Commission on Higher Education]] since January 2000. CFNR offers one [[undergraduate degree]] program ([[Bachelor of Science]] in Forestry) along with four other [[graduate degree]] programs and one two-year [[certificate program]]. Two of its professors, including its current [[dean (education)|dean]], are members of the [[Intergovernmental Panel for Climate Change]], the 2007 recipient of the [[Nobel Peace Prize]].<ref name='IPCC'>{{cite web | url = http://www.searca.org/web/news/2008/sep/web/23.html | title = Nobel Peace Prize 2007 goes to IPCC with 6 Filipino Scientist Members | author = Bernadette P. Joven | date = 2008-09-23 | accessdate = 2011-04-30 | publisher = Southeast Asian Regional Center for Graduate Study and Research and Agriculture | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110726120911/http://www.searca.org/web/news/2008/sep/web/23.html | archive-date = 2011-07-26 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref>
==History== [[File:Forestry building (1930).jpg|The School of Forestry building was built in commemoration of the school's 20th anniversary.<ref name="100 Years 0.5"/>|thumb|left]]
CFNR traces its roots to the Forest School founded in April 14, 1910,<ref name='Foundation'>{{cite journal | url = http://www.up.edu.ph/upnewsletter.php?issue=65&i=1182 | title = Forestry celebrates Centennial Week | author = Andre Encarnacion | journal = UP Newsletter | publisher = University of the Philippines | location = Quezon City | date = 2010-05-01 | accessdate = 2011-04-30 | volume = 31 | issue = 5 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120320042758/http://www.up.edu.ph/upnewsletter.php?issue=65&i=1182 | archive-date = 2012-03-20 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref> through an [[List of Philippine laws|Act]] 1989 by the [[Insular Government of the Philippines]] and efforts by Secretary of the Interior, [[Dean Conant Worcester]]. It was originally established as a department in the newly established of the College of Agriculture, and all of its early faculty were from the [[Department of Environment and Natural Resources|Bureau of Forestry]]. The Forest School became independent of the College of Agriculture in February 1916 through Act 2578. Since then directors of the bureau had acted as [[ex officio]] deans of the school.<ref name = '100 Years 0.5'>{{cite book| pages = 47–74 | chapter = Chs. 4–5 | chapterurl = http://www.slideshare.net/frankahilario/100-years-chapters-45 | accessdate = 2011-05-01 | year = 2007 | publisher = University of the Philippines Los Baños Alumni Association | location = Los Baños, Laguna | isbn = 978-971-547-252-4 | author = Fernando A. Bernardo |title = Centennial Panorama: Pictorial History of UPLB}}</ref><ref name = '100 Years 0'>{{cite book| pages = 3–46 | chapter = Chs. 1–3 | chapterurl = http://www.slideshare.net/guest4f33786/100-years-chapters-13 | accessdate = 2011-04-30 | year = 2007 | publisher = University of the Philippines Los Baños Alumni Association | location = Los Baños, Laguna | isbn = 978-971-547-252-4 | author = Fernando A. Bernardo |title = Centennial Panorama: Pictorial History of UPLB}}</ref> The Forest School changed its name to School of Forestry in 1924 by effect of Act 3095.<ref name='Forest History'>{{cite web | url = http://old.uplb.edu.ph/cfnr/about/history.html | title = History of CFNR | publisher = University of the Philippines Los Baños | accessdate = 2011-05-01 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110823155513/http://old.uplb.edu.ph/cfnr/about/history.html | archive-date = 2011-08-23 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref>
[[Americans in Philippine Scouting#Other BSA Philippine Islands Council Board Members, 1924–1937|Arthur Frederick Fischer]], the School of Forestry's first dean, retired as director of the Bureau of Forestry in February 1936. He was replaced by [[Florencio Tamesis]] who became the School of Forestry's second dean, as well as its first [[Filipino people|Filipino]] dean.<ref name = '100 Years 0.5'/>
The [[Second World War]] devastated the campus. All the School of Forestry buildings, including student and faculty houses, were destroyed. Large parts of the [[Mount Makiling|Makiling Forest Reserve]], which is administered by the school were likewise damaged. Only four faculty including Tamesis and silviculture professor Teodoro C. Delizo,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elib.gov.ph/details.php?uid=e6a3c7d8512263bc1f479867b0fe555d|title=Forest nursery and plantation handbook for the Philippines|author=Teodoro Cachero Delizo|date=1964|publisher=University of the Philippines}}</ref> along with five students returned upon the resumption of classes. Classes were held under trees until its buildings could be reconstructed through the help of [[war reparation]] funds worth [[Philippine Peso|₱]]59,300 (US$1,380).<ref name="conversion">Approximate conversion value as of May 2011</ref><ref name = '100 Years'>{{cite book | pages = 75–122 | chapter = Chs. 6–8 | chapterurl = http://www.slideshare.net/frankahilario/100-years-chapters-68 | accessdate = 2011-05-01 | year = 2007 | publisher = University of the Philippines Los Baños Alumni Association | location = Los Baños, Laguna | isbn = 978-971-547-252-4 | author = Fernando A. Bernardo |title = Centennial Panorama: Pictorial History of UPLB}}</ref>
The School of Forestry became the College of Forestry on June 14, 1949, by effect of RA 352,<ref name="Forest History"/><ref name='RA 352'>{{cite web | url = http://www.chanrobles.com/republicacts/republicactno352.html | title = Republic Act No. 352 | author = Congress of the Philippines | publisher = Chan Robles Virtual Law Library | date = 1949-06-04 | accessdate = 2011-05-02}}</ref> with the College of Forestry finally separated from the Bureau of Forestry in 1957, effectively putting it under direct administration of the [[University of the Philippines]].<ref name="100 Years"/>
In 1954 the College of Forestry signed an agreement with [[Cornell University]] for providing academic and financial assistance. The College of Forestry received [[visiting professor]]s from Cornell and grants that were used for construction and forestry research, while faculty and students were awarded scholarships for pursuing [[master's degree]]s at [[United States|US]] universities.<ref name="100 Years"/>
Domingo M. Lantican became the dean of the College of Forestry in May 1966. Lantican implemented a 5-year campus development program which included construction of new buildings and designating areas for [[dormitory|dormitories]] and staff housing.<ref name = '100 Years 2'>{{cite book| pages = 123–160 | chapter = Chs. 9–10 | chapterurl = http://www.slideshare.net/frankahilario/100-years-chapters-910 | accessdate = 2011-05-02 | year = 2007 | publisher = University of the Philippines Los Baños Alumni Association | location = Los Baños, Laguna | isbn = 978-971-547-252-4 | author = Fernando A. Bernardo |title = Centennial Panorama: Pictorial History of UPLB}}</ref>
The College of Forestry was reorganized to become the College of Forestry and Natural Resources on June 25, 1998.<ref name="Forest History"/> Since 2004 the event has been celebrated in concurrence with the [[Arbor Day|Philippine Arbor Day]], a nationwide event marked by extensive [[tree planting]].<ref name='arbor 2'>{{cite news | url = http://www.sanfernandocity.gov.ph/news/news77.php | title = City Vice Mayor urges continued re-greening program | author = William Jun Garcia | accessdate = 2011-05-10 | publisher = San Fernando City, La Union | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110725061440/http://www.sanfernandocity.gov.ph/news/news77.php | archive-date = 2011-07-25 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref><ref name='arbor 1'>{{cite web | url = http://ongkanon.uplb.edu.ph/index.php/news/306-cfnr-celebrates-arbor-day | title = CFNR celebrates Arbor Day | author = KS Tendero | date = 2010-07-22 | publisher = University of the Philippines Los Baños | accessdate = 2011-05-10 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110823172134/http://ongkanon.uplb.edu.ph/index.php/news/306-cfnr-celebrates-arbor-day | archive-date = 2011-08-23 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref>
==Campus== [[File:CFNR Campus map.png|thumb|right|300px|CNFR Campus map (click to enlarge)]] {{see also|Campus of University of the Philippines Los Baños}} The campus of the College of Forestry and Natural Resources, referred to as the "upper campus", is situated on the northeastern slope of Mount Makiling.<ref name='Makiling'>{{cite web|url = http://cfnr.uplb.edu.ph/index.php/about-cfnr.html | title = About | publisher = University of the Philippines Los Baños College of Forestry and Natural Resources | accessdate = 2011-05-05}}</ref> The campus contains academic buildings, dormitories, hosted institutions (such as the [[ASEAN Center for Biodiversity]]),<ref name ='ACB'>{{cite web | url = http://www.aseanbiodiversity.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=72&Itemid=86 | title = Contact Us | publisher = ASEAN Center for Biodiversity| accessdate = 2011-05-05}}</ref> and the 4,347-hectare<ref name='OVCRE'>{{cite web | url = http://ovcre.uplb.edu.ph/index.php/about-uplb-rde/resources-for-research-extension/9-facilities-equipment-and-library-resources | title = Facilities, Equipment and Library Resources | publisher = University of the Philippines Los Baños Office of the Vice-Chancellor for Research and Extension | accessdate = 2011-05-05 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110723073425/http://ovcre.uplb.edu.ph/index.php/about-uplb-rde/resources-for-research-extension/9-facilities-equipment-and-library-resources | archivedate = 2011-07-23 | df = }}</ref> Makiling Forest Reserve (MFR), which serves as an outdoor laboratory for forestry students<ref name='PCARRD'>{{cite web | url = http://pcarrd.dost.gov.ph/cin/watershed/gis/BAAA/bodyBAAA.htm | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090226221023/http://www.pcarrd.dost.gov.ph/cin/watershed/gis/BAAA/bodyBAAA.htm | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 2009-02-26 | title = Makiling Forest Reserve (MFR) | publisher = Philippine Council for Agriculture, Forestry and Natural Resources Research and Development | accessdate = 2011-05-05 }}</ref> and is believed to contain more tree species than the [[continental United States]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://rdenews.uplb.edu.ph/index.php/articles-by-the-media/14-internet-articles/255-mt-makiling-has-more-tree-species-than-us | title = Mt. Makiling has more tree species than US | publisher = Office of the Vice-Chancellor for Research and Extension | accessdate = 2011-05-05 | newspaper = Business Mirror | date = 2010-05-29 | author = Anjo C. Alimario | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110825174947/http://rdenews.uplb.edu.ph/index.php/articles-by-the-media/14-internet-articles/255-mt-makiling-has-more-tree-species-than-us | archivedate = 2011-08-25 | df = }}</ref>
Aside from being the location of the college, the MFR is also the site of the [[University of the Philippines Los Baños College of Public Affairs|College of Public Affairs]], [[National Arts Center]],<ref name='NAC'>{{cite web | url = http://www.culturalcenter.gov.ph/page.php?page_id=131 | title = National Arts Center | publisher = Cultural Center of the Philippines | accessdate = 2011-05-05 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110312104747/http://www.culturalcenter.gov.ph/page.php?page_id=131 | archivedate = 2011-03-12 | df = }}</ref> [[Philippine High School for the Arts]],<ref name='PHSA'>{{cite web | url = http://www.phsa.edu.ph/home.htm | title = Official website | publisher = Philippine High School of the Arts | accessdate = 2011-05-05 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110227002659/http://www.phsa.edu.ph/home.htm | archivedate = 2011-02-27 | df = }}</ref> the venue of the [[Jamboree (Scouting)|National Jamboree]] of the [[Boy Scouts of the Philippines]] (BSP),<ref name='Jamboree'>{{cite news | url = http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/nation/view/20071023-96321/17%2C000_boy_scouts_start_Jamboree_in_Mt._Makiling | title = 17,000 boy scouts start Jamboree in Mt. Makiling | newspaper = Manila Bulletin | author = Niña Catherine Calleja | date = 2007-10-23 | accessdate = 2011-05-05 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20121009171059/http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/nation/view/20071023-96321/17,000_boy_scouts_start_Jamboree_in_Mt._Makiling | archive-date = 2012-10-09 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref> the Center for Philippine Raptors<ref name='OAR'>{{cite web | url = http://up.edu.ph/~oarmain/?page_id=675&page=3 | title = UP Los Baños | publisher = University of the Philippines Office of Alumni Relations | accessdate = 2011-05-05 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101221002309/http://up.edu.ph/~oarmain/?page_id=675&page=3 | archivedate = 2010-12-21 | df = }}</ref> and the [[Bureau of Plant Industry (Philippines)|Bureau of Plant Industry]]-Makiling Botanic Gardens, one of the oldest parts of the campus. The gardens occupy the site where the tents were used as classrooms during the first four months of the university.<ref name="100 Years 0"/>
The MFR serves as an outdoor laboratory to students, primarily of the College of Forestry and Natural Resources. ₱5 million (US$156,000)<ref name="conversion"/> was designated for its conservation and development in 2011.<ref name='fund MFR'>{{cite book | chapterurl = http://www.dbm.gov.ph/GAA09/SUCS/NCR/A82.pdf | publisher = Department of Budget and Management | accessdate = 2011-05-22 | chapter = A.8. University of the Philippines System | url = http://www.dbm.gov.ph/GAA2011/section1.pdf | title = Republic Act No. 10147 | year = 2011 | author = Congress of the Philippines | page = 2 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110928173144/http://www.dbm.gov.ph/GAA2011/section1.pdf | archive-date = 2011-09-28 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref> The MFR was created in 1910 under the Bureau of Forestry. Jurisdiction over the MFR was transferred to the UP in 1960. [[National Power Corporation|NAPOCOR]] acquired complete jurisdiction of the MFR, however, in 1987 as part of the [[Philippines]]' [[energy development]] program under [[President of the Philippines|President]] [[Corazon Aquino]]. The MFR was returned to UPLB three years later by effect of [[Republic Act|RA]] 6967.<ref name='RA 6967'>{{cite web|url = http://www.lawphil.net/statutes/repacts/ra1990/ra_6967_1990.html | title = Republic Act No. 6967 | author = Congress of the Philippines | publisher = Arellano Law Foundation | date = 1990-10-15 | accessdate= 2011-04-16}}</ref><ref name='MFR'>{{cite web | url = http://pcarrd.dost.gov.ph/cin/watershed/gis/BAAA/bodyBAAA.htm | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090226221023/http://www.pcarrd.dost.gov.ph/cin/watershed/gis/BAAA/bodyBAAA.htm | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 2009-02-26 | title = Makiling Forest Reserve (MFR) | publisher = Philippine Council for Agriculture, Forestry and Natural Resources Research and Development | accessdate = 2011-04-16 }}</ref> In 2008 [[House of Representatives of the Philippines|representative]] Del De Guzman of the [[Legislative districts of Makati City|2nd district of Makati]] filed HB 1143 which, if passed into law, would have transferred jurisdiction of the MFR to the Boy Scouts of the Philippines. The [[bill (proposed law)|bill]] was strongly opposed by the UPLB, citing possible mismanagement and deforestation of the site if placed under the BSP among others.<ref name='Jamboree 1'>{{cite news | url = http://www.mb.com.ph/articles/192952/plans-put-mt-makiling-under-boy-scouts-opposed | date = 2008-11-21 | author = Ferdinand Castro | title = Plans to put Mt. Makiling under Boy Scouts opposed | newspaper = Manila Bulletin | accessdate = 2011-04-16 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120813072716/http://www.mb.com.ph/articles/192952/plans-put-mt-makiling-under-boy-scouts-opposed | archivedate = 2012-08-13 | df = }}</ref><ref name='Jamboree 2'>{{cite journal | url = http://www.up.edu.ph/upnewsletter.php?issue=47&i=767 | title = UPLB says no to House Bill 1143 | author = Bernice P. Varona | date = 2008-11-01 | volume = 29 | issue = 11 | journal = UP Newsletter | location = Quezon City | accessdate = 2011-04-16 | publisher = University of the Philippines | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120320042645/http://www.up.edu.ph/upnewsletter.php?issue=47&i=767 | archivedate = 2012-03-20 | df = }}</ref><ref name='Jamboree 3'>{{cite web | url = http://old.uplb.edu.ph/announce/1326 | title = UPLB says NO to House Bill 1143 and the fragmentation of the Mt. Makiling Forest Reserve | date = 2008-11-10 | publisher = University of the Philippines Los Baños | accessdate = 2011-04-16 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110823154614/http://old.uplb.edu.ph/announce/1326 | archivedate = 2011-08-23 | df = }}</ref><ref name='Jamboree 4'>{{cite journal | url = https://www.scribd.com/doc/11644791/uplb-perspective-0809-4th-ish | title = BSP eyes control of Jamboree | author = Nikko Angelo Oribiana | journal = UPLB Perspective | date = 2008-12-15 | volume = 35 | issue = 4 | page = 3 | accessdate = 2011-04-16}}</ref>
==Organization and administration== {| class="toccolours" style="float:right; margin-left:1em; font-size:90%; line-height:1.4em; width:300px;" ! colspan="2" style="text-align: center;background-color:#996633" | '''University of the Philippines Los Baños<br>College of Forestry and Natural Resources Deans''' |- | '''Name''' || '''Tenure in office''' |- | colspan="2" |<hr> |- | Arthur Frederick Fischer || 1917–1936 |- | Florencio Tamesis || 1937–1953 |- | Felipe Amos || 1954 |- | Calixto Mabesa || 1955–1958 |- | Gregorio Zamuco || 1959–1966 |- | Domingo Lantican || 1966–1972 |- | Romulo Del Castillo || 1972–1978 |- | Celso B. Lantican || 1978–1987 |- | Juan Adolfo Revilla || 1987–1989 |- | Virgilio Fernandez || 1989–1995 |- | Lucrecio Rebugio || 1995–2001 |- | Ramon Razal || 2002–2008 |- | Rex Victor O. Cruz || 2008–2012 |- | Juan M. Pulhin || 2012–present |- | colspan="2" | <hr> |- | style="font-size:70%" | References ||<ref name="100 Years 0.5"/><ref name="deans">{{cite news | date = 2010-04-30 | publisher = University of the Philippines Los Baños | newspaper = UPLB Link | author = AP Dominguita | title = April 19, PM: CLRIV exhorts CFNR to keep torch burning, strengthen culture of excellence | page = 4 | url = http://www.uplb.edu.ph/index.php/newsletters/doc_download/90-link-april-16-30-2010 | accessdate = 2011-05-07 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110723160958/http://www.uplb.edu.ph/index.php/newsletters/doc_download/90-link-april-16-30-2010 | archive-date = 2011-07-23 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref><ref name='Cruz'>{{cite web | url = http://cfnr.uplb.edu.ph/index.php/component/content/article/34-makiling-news/45-cruz-reappointed-as-cfnr-dean.html | title = Cruz reappointed as CFNR Dean | author = Aileen S. Peria | date = 2011-03-24 | accessdate = 2011-04-24 | publisher = University of the Philippines Los Baños College of Forestry and Natural Resources}}</ref> |}
The College of Forestry and Natural Resources is managed by a [[dean (education)|dean]], currently Juan M. Pulhin, who is appointed by the UP [[board of regents|Board of Regents]], and assisted by an associate dean.<ref name='Old CFNR'>{{cite web | url = http://old.uplb.edu.ph/cfnr | title = College of Forestry and Natural Resources | publisher = University of the Philippines Los Baños College of Forestry and Natural Resources | accessdate = 2011-05-07 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110823155320/http://old.uplb.edu.ph/cfnr | archive-date = 2011-08-23 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref> Prior to the college's separation from the Bureau of Forestry in 1957, the deans of the College of Forestry and its predecessors were not appointed by the board but were the directors of the Bureau of Forestry acting as ex officio heads of the college. Due to the distance of the Bureau of Forestry in Manila from the Forest School in [[Los Baños, Laguna|Los Baños]] (about 64 kilometers), directors of the bureau appointed foresters-in-charge to manage the school, a practice which continued until 1957.<ref name="100 Years 0.5"/><ref name="100 Years"/>
The College of Forestry and Natural Resources is a founding member of the Asia Pacific of Forestry Research Institutions,<ref name='APAFRI'>{{cite web | url = http://www.apafri.org/members2.html | title = Member Institutions: Country name J-V | publisher = Asia Pacific of Forestry Research Institutions | accessdate = 2011-05-07 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120405205014/http://www.apafri.org/members2.html | archive-date = 2012-04-05 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref> and the CFNR Institute of Agroforestry is a member of the Philippine Agroforestry Education and Research Network.<ref name='PAFERN 1'>{{cite web | url = http://www.pafern.org.ph/files/members.php | title = Member Institutions | publisher = Philippine Agroforestry Education and Research Network | accessdate = 2011-05-07}}</ref><ref name ='PAFERN 2'>{{cite web | url = http://www.uplb-iaf.org.ph/html/index.php?recid=4 | title = Linkages | publisher = University of the Philippines Los Baños College of Forestry and Natural Resources | accessdate = 2011-05-07}}</ref><ref name='linkages'>{{cite web | url = http://cfnr.uplb.edu.ph/index.php/rae-linkages.html | title = Research, Extension & Linkages | publisher = University of the Philippines Los Baños College of Forestry and Natural Resources | date = 2010-06-17 | accessdate = 2011-05-07}}</ref>
==Academics==
CFNR offers one [[undergraduate degree]] program ([[Bachelor of Science]] in [[Forestry]]), four [[graduate degree]] programs<ref name='grad degrees'>{{cite web | url = http://cfnr.uplb.edu.ph/index.php/academic-programs/graduate-programs.html | title = Graduate programs | publisher = University of the Philippines Los Baños College of Forestry and Natural Resources | date = 2011-05-11 | accessdate = 2011-05-22}}</ref> and one [[certificate program]].<ref name='Forest programs'>{{cite web | url = http://cfnr.uplb.edu.ph/index.php/academic-programs/undergraduate-programs.html | title = Undergraduate programs | date = 2011-05-11 | publisher = University of the Philippines Los Baños College of Forestry and Natural Resources | accessdate = 2011-05-22}}</ref> It started offering [[master's degree|master's]] and [[doctor's degree]]s in 1966 and 1973, respectively. The college produces about 100 graduates every year<ref name='A Statement on the Large Class Size Project'>{{cite book | url = http://uplb.edu.ph/email_attachments/2010-02-25_LargeClassStatement.pdf | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110723073420/http://uplb.edu.ph/email_attachments/2010-02-25_LargeClassStatement.pdf | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 2011-07-23 | title = A Statement on the Large Class Size Project | publisher = University of the Philippines Los Baños | accessdate = 2011-04-24 }}</ref> and has been identified as a "Center of Excellence" in [[forestry]] by the [[Commission on Higher Education (Philippines)|Philippine Commission on Higher Education]] since January 2000.<ref name="Forest History"/><ref name='coe2'>{{cite web | url = http://202.57.63.198/chedwww/index.php/eng/content/download/1125/6417/file/List_of_COEs-CODs_asof_04Oct2010.ods | title = List of Centers of Excellence and Centers of Development | publisher = Commission on Higher Education | accessdate = 2011-04-30 | date = 2010-10-04 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110704102451/http://202.57.63.198/chedwww/index.php/eng/content/download/1125/6417/file/List_of_COEs-CODs_asof_04Oct2010.ods | archivedate = 2011-07-04 | df = }}</ref>
Admission to the BS Forestry program is done through the [[University of the Philippines College Admission Test]], while a Certificate in Forestry applicants are screened by a test administered by CFNR.<ref name='cert test'>{{cite web | url = http://cfnr.uplb.edu.ph/index.php/component/content/article/58-student-announcements/89-2011-05-12-07-24-56.html | title = Application for Certificate in Forestry SY 2010-2011 | publisher = University of the Philippines Los Baños College of Forestry and Natural Resources | accessdate = 2011-05-22 | date = 2011-05-12}}</ref> Admission to graduate programs are managed by the [[University of the Philippines Los Baños Graduate School|Graduate School]].<ref name='CFNR admission'>{{cite web | url = http://cfnr.uplb.edu.ph/index.php/component/content/article/3-academics/8-admission.html | title = Admissions | publisher = University of the Philippines Los Baños College of Forestry and Natural Resources | accessdate = 2011-05-22}}</ref> Of its 394 students in 2008, 61 and 295 were enrolled in its Certificate in Forestry and BS Forestry programs, respectively, while the rest are in its graduate degree programs. As of 2009 it had 393 students enrolled in all of its programs.<ref name="A Statement on the Large Class Size Project"/> 38 of its faculty hold PhDs.<ref name='faculty'>{{cite web | url = http://old.uplb.edu.ph/cfnr/faculty.html | title = Faculty Profile | publisher = University of the Philippines Los Baños | accessdate = 2011-05-08 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110823155612/http://old.uplb.edu.ph/cfnr/faculty.html | archive-date = 2011-08-23 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref>
While all of its 20 students when the Forest School opened were male, more than 60% of the students of the college were female as of 2003. Women first enrolled in the college in 1951.<ref name="100 Years"/> Other forestry schools in the [[Philippines]] have also experienced a similar increase in female enrollment.<ref name="Forest Congress"/> {| style="font-size:90%; text-align:center; float:right; margin-left:1em" class="wikitable sortable" |+ Board exam performance |- ! class="unsortable" scope="col" | Year !! NP{{ref|a|[a]}} !! PR{{ref|b|[b]}} !! TN{{ref|c|[c]}} !! PI{{ref|d|[d]}} |- ! scope = "row" | 2010 | 42.10%<ref name='forester 2010 2'>{{Cite web | url = http://www.prc.gov.ph/documents/FORE0710ps.pdf | title = Performance of schools in alphabetical order (July 2010 Forester Licensure Examination) | publisher = Professional Regulation Commission | accessdate = 2011-05-22 | pages = 1–2 | date = July 2010 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110725031512/http://www.prc.gov.ph/documents/FORE0710ps.pdf | archive-date = 2011-07-25 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref> || 95.00%<ref name='forester 2010'>{{Cite web | url = http://www.prc.gov.ph/articles.asp?sid=4&aid=3681 | title = July 2010 Forester Licensure Examination results released in two (2) days | publisher = Professional Regulation Commission | date = 2010-07-13 | accessdate = 2011-05-22 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110725031542/http://www.prc.gov.ph/articles.asp?sid=4&aid=3681 | archive-date = 2011-07-25 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref> || 6<ref name="forester 2010"/> || 48<ref name="forester 2010 2"/> |- ! scope = "row" | 2009 | 36.55%<ref name='forester 2009 2'>{{Cite web | url = http://www.prc.gov.ph/documents/FORE0710ps.pdf | title = Performance of schools in alphabetical order (July 2009 Forester Licensure Examination) | publisher = Professional Regulation Commission | accessdate = 2011-05-22 | pages = 1–2 | date = July 2009 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110725031512/http://www.prc.gov.ph/documents/FORE0710ps.pdf | archive-date = 2011-07-25 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref> || 84.00%<ref name='forester 2009'>{{Cite web | url = http://www.prc.gov.ph/articles.asp?sid=4&aid=3157 | title = July 2009 Forester Licensure Examination results released in two (2) working days | publisher = Professional Regulation Commission | date = 2009-07-07 | accessdate = 2011-05-22 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110725031648/http://www.prc.gov.ph/articles.asp?sid=4&aid=3157 | archive-date = 2011-07-25 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref> || 4<ref name="forester 2009"/> || 47<ref name="forester 2009 2"/> |- ! scope = "row" | 2008 | 51.19%<ref name='forester 2008 2'>{{Cite web | url = http://www.prc.gov.ph/documents/FORE0708ps.pdf | title = Performance of schools in alphabetical order | publisher = Professional Regulation Commission | accessdate = 2011-05-22 | pages = 1–2 | date = July 2008 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110725031823/http://www.prc.gov.ph/documents/FORE0708ps.pdf | archive-date = 2011-07-25 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref> || 97.00%<ref name="forester 2008 2"/> || 4<ref name='forester 2008'>{{Cite web | url = http://www.prc.gov.ph/articles.asp?sid=4&aid=2658 | title = July 2008 Forester Licensure Examination results released in two (2) working days | publisher = Professional Regulation Commission | date = 2008-07-08 | accessdate = 2011-05-22 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110725031936/http://www.prc.gov.ph/articles.asp?sid=4&aid=2658 | archive-date = 2011-07-25 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref> || 43<ref name="forester 2008 2"/> |- class = "unsortable" ! scope = "row" | Mean | 43.26% || 92.49% || – || 46 |- class = "unsortable" | colspan="5" style="text-align:left; font-size:70%; border-style:solid hidden hidden; background:#FFF" | :'''Notes''' :#{{note|a}}National passing rate :#{{note|b}}CFNR passing rate :#{{note|c}}Number of CFNR examinees in the top ten :#{{note|d}}Number of participating institutions |}
The graduates of the college has maintained substantially good performance in the forestry license exams conducted by the [[Professional Regulation Commission]]. For instance, the mean passing rates of its graduates in the exams for the years 2008–2010 is 92.49%. This is almost double of the mean national passing rate for the same period. Furthermore, six of its graduates belonged to the top ten best performing students in the 2010 exam, while four belonged to the top ten in both 2008 and 2009 exams. (see table)
===Libraries and collections===
The CFNR Library holds about 30,000 [[publication]]s which mostly focus on forestry and related disciplines. The library has a floor area of 974.64 sq. m, and is open 40 hours a week.<ref name='CFNR library'>{{cite web | url = http://cfnr.uplb.edu.ph/index.php/cfnr-library.html | title = The CFNR Library | date = 2010-06-18 | publisher = University of the Philippines Los Baños College of Forestry and Natural Resources | accessdate = 2011-05-08}}</ref>
The Museum of Natural History of the University of the Philippines Los Baños, established in 1976, is located in the campus. It holds over 200,000 biological specimens; including half of the samplings from the Philippine Water Bug Inventory Project. More than half of the museum's specimens are in its [[entomology|entomological]] collection. While most of the museum's collections are in its main building, some are housed in other UPLB units.<ref name='Wien'>{{cite book| url = http://www.landesmuseum.at/pdf_frei_remote/ANNA_101B_0041-0042.pdf | publisher = Naturhistorischen Museums Wien | author = A.C. Sumalde | title = The Museum of Natural History, University of the Philippines Los Baños, and the Philippine Water Bug Inventory Project |date = December 1999| accessdate = 2011-05-08 | location = Vienna}}</ref>
===Research===
In 2002 the college had 94 researchers working in its eight research units.<ref name='number of researchers'>{{cite book | url = http://www.responsibleagroinvestment.org/rai/sites/responsibleagroinvestment.org/files/PhilippinesCR.pdf | pages = 67, 71 | chapter = Appendix D. Agencies included in survey sample, 2002 | title = Agricultural R&D in the Philippines: Policy, Investments and Institutional Profile | date = May 2007 | author = Gert-Jan Stads | author2 = Patricio S. Faylon | author3 = Leah J. Buendia | publisher = International Food Policy Research Institute; Philippine Council for Agriculture, Forestry and Natural Resources Research and Development | accessdate = 2011-05-22 }}{{Dead link|date=October 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> This includes the Makiling Center for Mountain Ecosystems, believed to be the first institution in the Philippines devoted to the study of mountain ecology. It also manages the [[Mount Makiling|Makiling Forest Reserve]] and has launched programs promoting its [[Conservation (ethic)|conservation]].<ref name='MCME'>{{cite web | url = http://cfnr.uplb.edu.ph/index.php/mcme.html | title = Makiling Center for Mountain Ecosystems | publisher = University of the Philippines Los Baños College of Forestry and Natural Resources | accessdate = 2011-05-22 | date = 2011-05-12}}</ref><ref name='MCME 2'>{{cite news | url = http://balita.ph/2009/04/09/mount-makiling-opens-up-again-to-hikers/ | title = Mount Makiling opens up again to hikers | date = 2009-04-09 | accessdate = 2011-05-08 | newspaper = Balita | agency = Philippine News Agency}}</ref>
The Forest Products Research and Development Institute, founded as the Forest Products Laboratory under the Bureau of Forestry in 1954, is hosted in the campus. Managed by the [[Department of Science and Technology (Philippines)|Department of Science and Technology]] of the [[government of the Philippines]],<ref name='DOST FPRDI'>{{cite web | url = http://fprdi.dost.gov.ph/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=42&Itemid=67 | title = History | publisher = Department of Science and Technology | date = 2008-07-01 | accessdate = 2011-05-08}}</ref> it is engaged in paper science<ref name='paper'>{{cite web | url = http://fprdi.dost.gov.ph/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=497&Itemid=103 | title = Paper and paper products | publisher = Department of Science and Technology | date = 2010-06-03 | accessdate = 2011-05-08}}</ref> and [[bioenergy]] research,<ref name='bioenergy'>{{cite web | url = http://fprdi.dost.gov.ph/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=99&Itemid=78 | title = Bio-energy, resins and oil | date = 2010-06-03 | accessdate = 2011-05-08 | publisher = Department of Science and Technology}}</ref> among others. It has also generated technologies such as those for [[biomass energy]] generation and [[construction]].<ref name='techno'>{{cite web | url = http://fprdi.dost.gov.ph/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=108&Itemid=80 | title = Technologies | date = 2010-08-19 | accessdate = 2011-05-08 | publisher = Department of Science and Technology}}</ref> Its facilities, believed to be the "largest and best equipped in the eastern hemisphere" by the time of its construction, were patterned after the [[University of Wisconsin]]'s [[Forest Products Laboratory]]. It was built using [[United States|US]] grants worth US$239,552 and funding from the Philippine government worth ₱518,000 (US$12,000).<ref name="conversion"/><ref name="100 Years"/> It had a total budget of almost ₱87 million (US$2.01 million)<ref name="conversion"/> in 2011, with about ₱51 million (US$1.18 million) of this appropriated for research.<ref name='forest products budget'>{{cite book | chapterurl = http://www.dbm.gov.ph/OPIF2010/DOST/FPRDI.pdf | chapter = Forest Products Research and Development Institute | publisher = Department of Budget and Management | page = 401 | year = 2011 | accessdate = 2011-05-22 | title = Republic Act No. 10147 | url = http://www.dbm.gov.ph/GAA2011/section1.pdf | author = Congress of the Philippines | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110928173144/http://www.dbm.gov.ph/GAA2011/section1.pdf | archive-date = 2011-09-28 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref>
==Extension==
The Training Center for Tropical Resources and Ecosystems Sustainability, established in June 1998 by the UP Board of Regents, offers more than 300 training programs in [[forest management|forest]] and [[land management]], [[logging]], and related disciplines. It has a satellite office in [[Baguio]] which offers similar programs.<ref name='TREES'>{{cite web | url = http://cfnr.uplb.edu.ph/index.php/trees.html?start=8 | title = Training Center for Tropical Resources and Ecosystems Sustainability | publisher = University of the Philippines Los Baños College of Forestry and Natural Resources | accessdate = 2011-05-22}}</ref><ref name='TREES 2'>{{cite web | url = http://cfnr.uplb.edu.ph/training%20brochure_pdf.pdf | title = 2011 International Training Sources | publisher = University of the Philippines Los Baños College of Forestry and Natural Resources | year = 2011 | accessdate = 2011-05-08 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110723073851/http://cfnr.uplb.edu.ph/training%20brochure_pdf.pdf | archive-date = 2011-07-23 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref><ref name='TREES 3'>{{cite web | url = http://www.fao.org/DOCREP/ARTICLE/WFC/XII/0436-C1.HTM | title = Reorienting Forestry Education to Sustainable Forest Development | author = Lucrecio L. Rebugio | author2 = Leni D. Camacho | publisher = XII World Forestry Congress | location = Quebec City | year = 2003 | accessdate = 2011-05-08}}</ref> Its programs are designed for professionals in working in the [[agroforestry]]-related disciplines and the wood industry.<ref name='TREES 4'>{{cite web | url = http://ovcre.uplb.edu.ph/index.php/trainings-at-uplb?layout=toggle&category_id=52# | title = Trainings at UPLB | publisher = University of the Philippines Los Baños Office of the Vice-Chancellor for Research and Extension | accessdate = 2011-05-22}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://cfnr.uplb.edu.ph/}}
{{University of the Philippines Los Baños}}
